questions.clue: During the Edo period, this type of sushi, known for its vinegared rice, became popular in Edo, now Tokyo.
This network of roads, including the Tokaido, was developed to connect Edo with the rest of Japan.
First introduced in the Edo period, this type of theatre is characterized by its elaborate costumes and dynamic acting.
These distinctive clay figures, made in the shape of humans and animals, were traditionally used in Edo period rituals.
This Edo period innovation was a way of printing books using carved wooden blocks, allowing for mass production.
This type of sushi, often featuring raw fish atop vinegared rice, is commonly found in Edo-style sushi.
In the Edo period, sushi was originally a quick snack sold by street vendors in this city, now known as Tokyo.
Norway introduced salmon as a sushi fish to Japan in the 1980s, popularizing it with this type of sushi.
This American sushi roll, often containing avocado, crab, and cucumber, was invented in Los Angeles in the 1960s.
This type of sushi, where fish is pressed onto rice in a wooden mold, originated in Osaka and differs from the Edo period nigiri style.
This is the only even prime number.
In the Edo period, Japanese mathematician Seki Takakazu made significant advances in this field, the study of shapes, sizes, and properties of space.
Sushi chefs often use this mathematical concept to ensure even slicing; it divides a whole into equal parts.
This famous sequence, named after an Italian mathematician, is found in nature and sushi presentation, starting with 0, 1.
This method, used by Seki Takakazu, was a Japanese approach to solving polynomial equations, comparable to calculus in the West.
This 1605 work by Miguel de Cervantes is considered the first modern novel.
Published in 1851, this novel by Herman Melville was one of the first to use a character as a narrator in a non-linear story.
This 1922 work by James Joyce is often credited as being the first major stream of consciousness novel.
Considered the first novel of the Edo period, The Tale of Genji was written by this Japanese noblewoman.
This 1759 satire is considered the first major novel written in English by a French author.
This sea creature from Greek mythology is known for its many heads, each of which grows back if cut off.
In Japanese folklore, this creature is a shape-shifting fox often associated with the Shinto deity Inari.
This mythical bird from Arabian mythology is said to be reborn from its ashes after bursting into flames.
This creature from Irish folklore is known for hoarding pots of gold and is often associated with rainbows.
From the Edo period, this giant snake-like creature is believed to live in remote mountain regions of Japan and is said to bring misfortune.

final.clue: This sushi variety, which originated in the Edo period, is known for its quick preparation method involving vinegar-seasoned rice and fresh fish, and shares its name with a bustling district in Tokyo.
